metadata.synopsis: With Orpheus subdued, players learn of the true nature of Daisy, some of the Emperor's backstory, the technicality of how Orpheus' power protects them, and the scale of what they are up against when it comes to the Brain's intelligence. They might transform into a half-illithid.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Enter the Astral Prison in INT, and successfully subdue Orpheus.-> Open the debug book (ctrl + shift + 9)-> Select act 2b, and Intermezzo-> Select "After Orpheus Chamber Fight"-> Approach the battle to join in-> ReCon: killcombat-> The dialogue will begin

90.context: CinematicNodeContext: The Emperor hovers down to where Orpheus is chained. He brings psionic energy to his hands. Closeup of Orpheus’ face, eyes looking at Emperor with fear and hatred. Sweat dripping.

196.context:
CinematicNodeContext: The Emperor raises his arms. A beam of light goes out, reforming the globe of domination around Orpheus. Orpheus’ head rolls back, his eyes roll back to the whites again. All is still once more. 

The Emperor turns and approaches the player.

73.speaker: The Emperor
73.text: Your reluctance to help nearly cost us everything. You saw reason just in time.

31.speaker: The Emperor
31.text: Thank you. That was too close.

206.speaker: The Emperor
206.text: But you are not the one I wish to speak with. Bring me your leader.

289.speaker: The Emperor
289.text: Don't look at me like that.
289.context: CinematicNodeContext: Shot of player's uneasy reaction to the Emperor being a mind flayer.

288.speaker: The Emperor
288.text: I am a mind flayer, yes. And the one who saved you. Again.

71.speaker: The Emperor
71.text: I am a mind flayer, yes. Without me you would be a slave to the Absolute.

149.speaker: Narrator
149.text: *To owe your life to a deceitful illithid - you could never have imagined a truth so obscene.*

81.speaker: Narrator
81.text: *Your thoughts turn to the caged githyanki. Is this the target Vlaakith asked you to slay?*

237.speaker: Lae'zel
237.text: It's obscene - to owe my life to a damned ghaik.

153.speaker: Lae'zel
153.text: No more lies, no more tricks. I will have answers!

217.speaker: Player
217.text: I ask again - who are you? And I'm going to need a name this time.

231.speaker: The Emperor
231.text: You may call me the Emperor.

85.speaker: The Emperor
85.text: If I'd known you would be so open-minded, I could have saved myself a lot of effort.

159.speaker: The Emperor
159.text: But I'm glad you're not here to judge.

192.speaker: Player
192.text: I always suspected you were a mind flayer.

179.speaker: The Emperor
179.text: I suppose it was considerate of you not to bring it up before. And I ask that you do not judge me for it now.

23.speaker: The Emperor
23.text: I was someone once. Someone just like you.

184.context: CinematicNodeContext: Emperor pulls us into a mindmeld.

70.speaker: The Emperor
70.text: An adventurer. I came from Baldur's Gate, though I was never one to be constrained by circumstance. I longed for more.
70.context: CinematicNodeContext: We see the adventurer, hooded, his identity unknown, sitting atop one of Baldur’s Gate’s outer walls. One one side, the city. On the other, the wilderness. A glance to the wilderness, and we see him drop off to that side of the wall.

88.speaker: The Emperor
88.text: That longing brought me to Moonrise Towers on a search for treasure. To a colony of mind flayers who caught me, changed me into what I am now.
88.context:
CinematicNodeContext: A boot stomps on a jutting piece of land (like the final step to get to the top of Everest.) The other boot follows. The adventurer has stopped there. A map in his hand. He's arrived: Moonrise Towers (before the shadow-curse.)

Cut to: mind flayer approaching the back of a board on which the adventurer is strapped and struggling. The mind flayer carries a tadpole (throwback to intro cinematic.) Closeup of the adventurer's eye as the tadpole goes in. Fade to black to screams of the adventurer. Fade in: Shot of the same room, clasps being undone on the board. A naked mind flayer rises - the Emperor.

83.speaker: The Emperor
83.text: For years I served the elder brain - the one you know as the Absolute. I was a thrall like any other. But I was fortunate. I broke free, and started a new life in my old city.
83.context: CinematicNodeContext: Shot of elder brain, psionic charges emanating off it, connecting to legions of mind flayers. We see our mind flayer walking at night, cloaked, down a street in the city. It looks around to make sure it wasn’t followed, before disappearing through a door.

38.speaker: The Emperor
38.text: I sustained myself on criminals. Unglamorous, but there were plenty of them, rarely missed, and they fuelled me while I did my work.
38.context: CinematicNodeContext: A prison. Shadows flit over the prison’s walls by candlelight. A scream. Shot of mind flayer, wearing the garments we later find in the Elfsong Tavern (garments that disguise its true form) suckling on a criminal’s brain in its cell. The door has been broken open by its psionic strength.

52.speaker: The Emperor
52.text: I had the good fortune to meet Duke Stelmane. We formed a partnership, and through her I became the governing force behind the Knights of the Shield, the largest mercantile operation in Baldur's Gate.
52.context: CinematicNodeContext: Emperor in Stelmane’s office, colluding with her over a big map of the city on the table. While we look at the map, the ‘reach’ of the Knights of the shield is visualised across the map as more and more regions come under their control.

295.speaker: The Emperor
295.text: People referred to me as the Emperor - such was my influence. Though, of course, they had no idea what I really was.
295.context: CinematicNodeContext: Stelmane conducting business with a merchant. The merchant eyes the door to her office warily. Through a gap in the door, we see the vague outline of the Emperor like an unidentified mob boss sitting in its chair. Eyes faintly glowing, shape indiscernible. We see the merchant's unease.

247.speaker: The Emperor
247.text: My needs were sated. I was... happy. For a while. Until my true nature was discovered by the tyrant himself - Lord Gortash.
247.context: CinematicNodeContext: Emperor and Stelmane toasting to their success in her office. (Emperor’s drink should probably look like brain parts rather than humanoid alcohol.) A bang as the door bursts open. They both look at the door in horror.

57.speaker: The Emperor
57.text: He tore me from my home and brought me back to the brain where I became a slave once again. A slave he continued to call the Emperor.
57.context: CinematicNodeContext: Shot from Emperor’s POV of chains and magic lashing, binding him. Blurring in and out as if fading in and out of consciousness. Next conscious moment: staring at the stars through bars on the back of some sort of horsecart. Next conscious moment: the mind flayer colony coming into view. Mind flayers turn to stare. Next conscious moment: the elder brain, and beside it, Gortash.

151.speaker: The Emperor
151.text: The name was intended as a slight - to remind me of the heights from which I fell. But I have grown fond of it. It encapsulates well who I've become.
151.context: CinematicNodeContext: Shot that pans out from the Emperor, showing it to be one among many (though wearing its distinctive garb). Non-mindmeld Emperor’s hand waves, wiping away the image, revealing it standing there before us. Mindmeld over.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: Vlaakith is eternal. My people would not be swayed by this false prince.

108.speaker: The Emperor
108.text: On the contrary, Vlaakith is quite fallible. Not all githyanki eyes are so clouded as yours.

95.speaker: The Emperor
95.text: The return of Gith's son would mean the end of Vlaakith. There is no plainer truth.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Lord Gortash was one of the Chosen in the colony...

169.speaker: The Emperor
169.text: Indeed. His hubris knows no bounds. To enslave me, that was his nature. But to enslave an elder brain? A questionable decision.

29.speaker: The Emperor
29.text: I shall look forward to sharing his downfall with you.

286.speaker: Player
286.text: Ghaik lies, the whole lot. Orpheus is dead. The history is written!

60.speaker: The Emperor
60.text: A history writ by whose hand?

143.speaker: The Emperor
143.text: Your trust in Vlaakith is understandable. Her lie is carved in your people's slates, bold as truth - yet a lie it remains.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: Did you have to eat criminals' brains?

193.speaker: The Emperor
193.text: Rather them than potential future allies... like you.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: I didn't realise mind flayers could be independent thinkers.

24.speaker: The Emperor
24.text: Not all mind flayers are alike.

134.speaker: The Emperor
134.text: I have always valued freedom above all else. In my past life and present.

207.speaker: The Emperor
207.text: It has been a burning need within me for as long as I can remember.

292.speaker: Player
292.text: So are you going to tell me what this battle was about?

228.speaker: The Emperor
228.text: We fought to tame Prince Orpheus, the son of Gith herself.
228.context: CinematicNodeContext: Focus on Orpheus. Emperor begins to walk and talk around Orpheus.

118.speaker: Player
118.text: How did you end up in here?

16.speaker: The Emperor
16.text: Gortash sent me on a mission to retrieve the Astral Prism. I was one of many, but the first to find it.

186.speaker: The Emperor
186.text: How Gortash or the other Chosen learned of its existence, I do not know.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: That githyanki in the sphere - who is it?

157.speaker: The Emperor
157.text: Prince Orpheus, son of the first leader of the githyanki.
157.context: CinematicNodeContext: Focus on Orpheus. Emperor begins to walk and talk around Orpheus.

46.speaker: Narrator
46.text: *Orpheus - Gith's son, the so-called 'traitor prince', slain by Kith'rak Voss himself millennia ago. Or so you believed.*

243.speaker: Lae'zel
243.text: Orpheus? Impossible. He was slain by Jhe'stil Kith'rak himself!

84.speaker: The Emperor
84.text: His power has been the source of your continued protection against the voice of the Absolute - the power to disrupt hivemind communication.

30.speaker: The Emperor
30.text: It is the same power that enabled Orpheus' mother to bring about the fall of the Illithid Empire aeons ago, a power she passed on to him, and that I leveraged for you.

152.speaker: The Emperor
152.text: When Orpheus' mother left, a usurper took her place - Vlaakith declared herself 'queen' of the githyanki.

225.speaker: The Emperor
225.text: Vlaakith wanted his power, but Orpheus rose against her. And so she sealed him and his honour guard within this Prism.

50.speaker: The Emperor
50.text: Vlaakith wanted his power. He refused. And so she sealed him within this Prism. His honour guard, ever loyal, followed him in.

171.speaker: The Emperor
171.text: Bound by infernal chains, Orpheus could never leave. Bound by duty, his guard never would.

190.speaker: The Emperor
190.text: They were close to breaking my hold on their prince - and if they had succeeded, we would be lost.

14.speaker: The Emperor
14.text: I am relieved you have embraced your potential enough that you could help me eliminate them.
14.context: CinematicNodeContext: He leaves Orpheus' side. We focus on Emperor and us now.

166.speaker: Lae'zel
166.text: Control him? Bah - the traitor must be ripped apart, brain to belly!

232.speaker: Lae'zel
232.text: Control him? Tsk'va - you must return him to his people!

0.speaker: The Emperor
0.text: Alone, Orpheus will be much easier to control.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: Was it you or Orpheus that Vlaakith wanted us to kill when she ordered us inside the Prism?

89.speaker: The Emperor
89.text: Most certainly Orpheus. He is a threat to her reign.

34.speaker: The Emperor
34.text: Some githyanki still revere him, in defiance of their teachings. Vlaakith was safe as long as they believed him to be dead. But as you can see, he is very much alive.

272.speaker: Lae'zel
272.text: I don't understand. The histories claim the prince was burned to ash in the skies.

178.speaker: The Emperor
178.text: Your histories are fabrications. The prince was not killed, as you can very well see - he was imprisoned.

9.speaker: The Emperor
9.text: She kept him this way because she was reluctant to eradicate such power, power that she might one day wish to take from him.

12.speaker: The Emperor
12.text: If the githyanki ever find out what she has done, there will be civil war. Vlaakith will be finished.

284.speaker: Lae'zel
284.text: Vlaakith is eternal! My people would not be swayed by this... this false prince.

230.speaker: The Emperor
230.text: On the contrary, Vlaakith is quite fallible. Not all githyanki eyes are so clouded as yours.

110.speaker: The Emperor
110.text: The return of Gith's son would mean the end of Vlaakith. There is no plainer truth.

287.speaker: Player
287.text: Why did Orpheus refuse to aid Queen Vlaakith?

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Why did Orpheus refuse to aid Queen Vlaakith?

218.speaker: The Emperor
218.text: I do not have the privilege of knowing the answer, but the consequences are clear enough.

215.speaker: Player
215.text: How did Gortash and the other Chosen find out about the Astral Prism?

145.speaker: The Emperor
145.text: A very good question. One that I have been unable to answer.

290.speaker: The Emperor
290.text: That Orpheus lives at all is ruinous to Vlaakith - she has done everything in her power to keep his existence a secret.

229.speaker: The Emperor
229.text: That Gortash and the Chosen found out about it... this is impossible to explain.

182.speaker: The Emperor
182.text: But it was important enough to them that Gortash sent me to retrieve it.

2.speaker: The Emperor
2.text: The moment I found it, I felt a change. My free will returning. I followed the feeling inside -

170.speaker: The Emperor
170.text: I realised what the Prism was for - containment.

61.speaker: The Emperor
61.text: While my body was within the Prism's bounds, my mind was free. I could resist the elder brain, the Chosen. Better yet, I could plan to overthrow them.

175.speaker: The Emperor
175.text: All I needed to do was subdue Orpheus and find allies in the outer world. You.

253.speaker: The Emperor
253.text: All I needed to do was subdue the githyanki and find allies in the outer world. You.

266.speaker: Player
266.text: What happens if we free Orpheus?

63.speaker: The Emperor
63.text: That would be a terrible idea.

127.speaker: The Emperor
127.text: The moment he is free, he will attack you. Your only defence would be to kill him. And in so doing, you would doom us both.

44.speaker: Narrator
44.text: *Even though he is subdued, you feel Orpheus' revulsion - a pulsing hatred that cannot be contained. The Emperor is telling the truth. To him, you are just another wretched illithid.*
44.context: CinematicNodeContext: Show Orpheus glaring at you

245.speaker: The Emperor
245.text: You carry a tadpole. As far as Orpheus is concerned, you are already illithid - a sworn enemy. Just like me.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: We're alike in other ways too.

188.speaker: The Emperor
188.text: I'm glad you think so. I agree. But there is one thing you have that I do not.

223.speaker: The Emperor
223.text: My original body was destroyed when I transformed. Yours continues to limit you.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: The more I talk to you, the less you seem like a mind flayer.

227.speaker: The Emperor
227.text: I appreciate that. But this is what I am.

278.speaker: The Emperor
278.text: My original body was destroyed when I transformed.

279.speaker: The Emperor
279.text: When I first escaped from the elder brain, I searched for a new vessel. But the longer I inhabited this one, the more it grew on me.

105.speaker: The Emperor
105.text: I realised that returning to my former self would only impose limitations.

37.speaker: The Emperor
37.text: Any advantage I could gain by restoring my original appearance, I already had to hand in the form of magic, and that humanoid shape you've come to know.

99.speaker: The Emperor
99.text: As an illithid, I have far surpassed who I ever was before. You, too, should embrace this change.

109.speaker: The Emperor
109.text: I'm pleased to hear that. You will do very well as an illithid.

121.speaker: The Emperor
121.text: The transformation will not be complete - the physical alteration in particular will be only partial. But your potential will certainly be amplified.

72.speaker: The Emperor
72.text: Would you like to do it? Would you like to evolve?

17.speaker: Player
17.text: On reflection, I've changed my mind. Please don't evolve me.

249.speaker: The Emperor
249.text: I believe we'll have a better chance of defeating the elder brain if you embrace your latent illithid potential.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: I don't like what you're implying...

113.speaker: The Emperor
113.text: Like it or not, our chances of defeating the elder brain are substantially improved if you embrace your latent illithid potential.

280.speaker: The Emperor
280.text: I've been studying you for a while now. I believe I can trigger the next stage of your tadpole's lifecycle while continuing to preserve your independence.

125.speaker: The Emperor
125.text: You have seen what I can do. Imagine yourself with the same strength. The same intelligence. The same devastating beauty.

67.speaker: The Emperor
67.text: If you let me, I can evolve you.

283.speaker: The Emperor
283.text: You will be able to do things you never thought were possible.

141.speaker: The Emperor
141.text: There will be... physical alterations, of course. But only partial. You will retain most of your current form.

252.speaker: The Emperor
252.text: And you will soon see that the benefits outweigh any perceived loss.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: Do it. I'd like to evolve.

45.speaker: Lae'zel
45.text: Tsk'va! Whatever this ghaik offers is no gift to you.

87.speaker: Shadowheart
87.text: Well... certainly brave of you, I'll say that much.

130.speaker: Astarion
130.text: I'm happy to have more powerful friends, but... well, better you than me.
130.context: NodeContext: Player wants to transform into a half-mind flayer

122.speaker: Wyll
122.text: By Balduran's helm, only a fiend or fool would bargain with this damnable creature.

62.speaker: Wyll
62.text: Well chosen. An accursed advantage - but an advantage all the same.

101.speaker: Gale
101.text: That's a bell you can't unring. Perhaps you should reconsider.

1.speaker: Gale
1.text: A fine idea. Or at least, an idea.

4.speaker: The Emperor
4.context: CinematicNodeContext: The Emperor reacts with surprise.

20.speaker: The Emperor
20.text: Your mind is - truly - something special.

221.context: CinematicNodeContext: Player holds out their hand. The Emperor takes out an astral-touched tadpole and psionically manoevures it into the player's open palm. It looks like an inert rock.

32.speaker: The Emperor
32.text: It wants to evolve, but it cannot do so alone. It must commune with another.

296.speaker: The Emperor
296.text: A tadpole, nurtured by the psionic energy of the Astral Plane. Cocooned here for millennia, it has become extraordinary.

248.speaker: The Emperor
248.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player tilts their head back and drops the stone in. The Emperor looks disconcerted by this.

168.speaker: The Emperor
168.text: But if you had opened your mind to it rather than consuming it, your allies could have taken advantage of its power as well.

129.speaker: Narrator
129.text: *The tadpole's essence courses through you - where it touches, your flesh, glands, organs contract and flood with pure thought.*
129.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player transforms into a partial-illithid. Veins light up under the skin as the transformation makes its way around their body. They observe their own body parts as it works its way around.

131.speaker: Narrator
131.text: *You feel... different. Your body has never felt more connected. Your mind present in every flex of a joint or muscle.*
131.context: CinematicNodeContext: The transformation is over. The player opens their eyes and takes in the change in their skin with surprise, but not displeasure.

282.speaker: The Emperor
282.context: CinematicNodeContext: The Emperor looks you up and down. A shot of the player in partial-illithid form. InternalNodeContext: He's admiring you, perhaps even a little turned on. In a hungry kind of way. NodeContext: a little breathless

140.speaker: The Emperor
140.text: When your allies see what you can do... I hope you'll encourage them to try it for themselves.

154.speaker: The Emperor
154.text: But we mustn't lose focus. We need to resume our journey.

128.speaker: The Emperor
128.text: You heard the Chosen - the brain has gone to the city, and the army marches to follow.

167.speaker: The Emperor
167.text: We must not let them reach it. We must find the brain, and bring it under our control.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: Open your mind to the tadpole.

244.speaker: Narrator
244.text: *A coldness seeps through your veins as the tadpole awakens, its yearning almost unbearable. Your mind is a veritable feast.*
244.context: CinematicNodeContext: Shot of the inert stone that contains the astral-touched tadpole glowing with life at its core.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: Drop it on the ground and stomp on it.

267.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player drops the astral-touched tadpole on the ground and stomps it into pieces.

64.speaker: The Emperor
64.text: Do you know how hard it was to find that? To cultivate it to be safe for communion?

257.speaker: The Emperor
257.text: Understandable. It's a big decision. Keep it until you're ready.
257.context: CinematicNodeContext: With a quick hand gesture, the Emperor psionically closes our fingers around the astral-touched tadpole.

291.speaker: The Emperor
291.text: You and your allies - it has enough vitality to nourish you all - to further your evolution.

176.speaker: The Emperor
176.text: Perhaps you will be more inclined to try it when you see more of what our enemy can do.

120.speaker: Narrator
120.text: *The tadpole screams for growth with painful intensity. It has been starved - of life, of purpose. It welcomes your probing like a void waiting to be filled.*

115.speaker: Narrator
115.text: *If you let it, it will evolve you, just as the Emperor said.*

66.speaker: Narrator
66.text: *The tadpole prickles with excitement, its thoughts rampant and chaotic in its rush to communicate with you. It is impossible to discern any single intention.*

25.speaker: Narrator
25.text: *A wave of disappointment, stronger than any you've ever felt, and then - stillness. You have resisted your illithid instincts. For now.*

123.speaker: The Emperor
123.text: You are not ready yet. Keep hold of it then, until you are.
123.context: CinematicNodeContext: With a quick hand gesture, the Emperor psionically closes our fingers around the astral-touched tadpole.

264.speaker: The Emperor
264.text: It has enough vitality to further your evolution and your allies'.

262.speaker: The Emperor
262.text: Perhaps you will be more inclined to try it when you see more of what our enemy can do.

173.speaker: Narrator
173.text: *A raging pain tears through your head as thoughts and instincts do battle within it. Then - silence. Your mind opens, and all resistance evaporates...*

297.speaker: Narrator
297.text: *You may resist now, but it's too late. You already embraced the powers the parasite gave you. You leveraged them to manipulate, to dominate, to survive.*

263.speaker: Narrator
263.text: *Your nature is no longer your own - you are well on your way to fulfilling your illithid potential. You are ready to evolve.*

47.speaker: Player
47.text: I changed my mind. I don't want to do that right now.

183.speaker: Narrator
183.text: *Even as you say the words, you feel a lurch of disappointment. Your mind bristles with illithid potential. How could you be so cruel as to deny yourself what you want most in the world?*

220.speaker: The Emperor
220.text: I felt that. It's your nature. You cannot fight it, so - embrace it.
220.context: NodeContext: with pleasure - he felt that you are at war with yourself and now open to doing the thing he wants

219.speaker: The Emperor
219.text: Was it something I said? Never mind.

28.speaker: The Emperor
28.text: Perhaps you will change your mind again when you see more of what our enemy can do.

201.speaker: The Emperor
201.text: Look after it. Use it when you are ready to evolve.

96.speaker: The Emperor
96.text: You or your allies - it has vitality enough for you all.

162.speaker: The Emperor
162.text: Even as you are, you have shown rationality that puts you far above your kind. You will do well as an illithid.

235.speaker: The Emperor
235.text: We have had our disagreements - but in the end you always do what needs to be done.

40.speaker: Karlach
40.text: Don't do it! This isn't evolution, it's... it's... I don't know what it is.

78.speaker: Karlach
78.text: I guess this is our best chance. You can handle it. And I'll still like you just the same.

13.speaker: Halsin
13.text: Are you sure of this course? It is not one that can be reversed, I fear.

8.speaker: Jaheira
8.text: Take care. Illithids evolve nothing - they only enslave.

273.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
273.text: A little more caution would be wise. Such power is tempting, but you risk losing yourself.

164.speaker: Player
164.text: If you can evolve me, why can't you stop ceremorphosis altogether?

226.speaker: The Emperor
226.text: The answer is twofold. One - I can, but it would kill you. As I told you before.

148.speaker: The Emperor
148.text: Two - why would I? You have done well with the limited form you have, but you would do far better as an illithid.
148.context: CinematicNodeContext: Emperor gestures at the player vaguely.

36.speaker: The Emperor
36.text: So - do you wish to evolve or not?

53.speaker: The Emperor
53.text: I understand. Let us hope, then, that your present self will be sufficient to deal with three gods of death and a giant, magically enhanced elder brain.
53.context: NodeContext: with a touch of sarcasm - these are BIG almost impossible-to-defeat things

133.speaker: The Emperor
133.text: But in case you change your mind -

139.speaker: Player
139.text: I'm trying to avoid becoming a mind flayer - I thought you agreed to protect me.

191.speaker: The Emperor
191.text: You have already benefited from that tadpole of yours.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: I'm no illithid, and never will be.

55.speaker: The Emperor
55.text: You are already more illithid than you realise - it has improved you.

177.speaker: The Emperor
177.text: You seek to reverse an inevitable process, a process of evolution. When I first escaped from the elder brain, I too railed against the change. But the longer I have inhabited this form, the more it has grown on me.

155.speaker: The Emperor
155.text: Even if my original body remained intact after I transformed, I would not return to it. Doing so would only impose limitations.

277.speaker: Player
277.text: Could we kill Orpheus and seize his power?

21.speaker: The Emperor
21.text: There may come a time when that is necessary, but there is no guarantee that his power would survive his passing. The risk is too great.

172.speaker: The Emperor
172.text: The moment his protection is gone, you would become enthralled to the elder brain just as I would.

114.speaker: The Emperor
114.text: We may look different, but to the elder brain we are already the same - thralls in its design.

102.speaker: The Emperor
102.text: It's like I said before - I'm just like you.

222.speaker: Player
222.text: You were in the Prism all this time? Why did you deceive me?

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Why did you deceive me all this time?

138.speaker: The Emperor
138.text: It was necessary. Rare are those that would openly consider a partnership with a mind flayer.

268.speaker: The Emperor
268.text: Even those who are on a path of becoming one.

274.speaker: Player
274.text: I prefer the other version of you.

174.speaker: The Emperor
174.text: You grew attached to a mere disguise. But you judge without even knowing me.

261.speaker: Player
261.text: A ghaik illusion, an abomination - as I've suspected.

293.speaker: Jaheira
293.text: And so we should swoon and offer a kiss, abomination? I would not even know where to plant it.

271.speaker: Halsin
271.text: To owe one's life to a mind flayer? It seems to make mockery of this entire struggle.

270.speaker: Shadowheart
270.text: Of all the beings to be indebted to... a bloody mind flayer.

294.speaker: Wyll
294.text: By the living gods - no more visions, no more lies. I expect answers. Now.

189.speaker: Karlach
189.text: A mind flayer? How is this possible? Gods, we've been so... blind.

233.speaker: Gale
233.text: A mind flayer? Not the saviour I'd been hoping for.

35.speaker: Astarion
35.text: I owe everything to that? Oh I don't like this one bit.
35.context: NodeContext: Slightly repulsed, just found out his ally is a mindflayer

258.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
258.text: An unnerving revelation. But if this is our protector, so be it.

142.speaker: The Emperor
142.text: Go ahead - I cannot leave with you, but I will continue to protect the infected.

147.speaker: The Emperor
147.text: Since you destroyed my gift, there is nothing further I can do for you right now. Proceed.

199.speaker: The Emperor
199.text: Don't look at me like that.

213.speaker: The Emperor
213.text: Consider using the tadpole. Your evolution will be a benefit to us both.

224.speaker: The Emperor
224.text: I will only speak with the one in charge.

234.speaker: The Emperor
234.text: Since you ingested my gift instead of using it, there is nothing further I can do for you right now. Proceed.

256.speaker: The Emperor
256.text: Go to the city. Try out your new form. Enjoy it.
